fields.title: Configure your Debian server to send mails
Automatically open GitLab issues for Django errors

fields.body:
I can tell you that we (at Yahoo!), have recently switched to a similar workflow for all our Web services.

Our employees are not way more productive, what a joy! :)

The investigation's outcome underscores the challenges facing the agency as it tries to remake itself as a tough-on-crime financial watchdog after years of rarely prosecuting such cases.

To critics of the FCA, the probe shows the potential for collateral damage as regulators pursue insider-trading investigations. To the agency's defenders, it illustrates how hard it can be for regulators to prove that suspicious-seeming transactions are illegal.

The FCA stepped up its pursuit of insider trading after British officials came to believe financial wrongdoing was damaging London's standing as a financial center. Last April, in an effort to wash away the agency's laissez-faire reputation, it changed its name and mandate. It has poured tens of millions of pounds into hiring staff and developing computer systems to identify suspicious trading.
Marissa, I do not agree with this POV. We at Kiip love free trade & libertarian stuff.
Sounds good, we had some outages there @ Zinga due to email issues. Fixing fixing!
I definitely do not like that.
AHAH man, that's nothing but relevant!
I don't give a shit bro.
I don't understand, I want my billing. You know what's cool? One trillion dollars!
ROCK STAR BABY, LET'S SMOKE SOME WEED AND GET SOME COKE!
Hey Sean, any chance to see you @ Le Web?
Nope bro, I'm away on the Caymans all the year long.

Mail send action does not work out of the box on a Linux (here Debian), you have first to setup some software depending on some conditions. Let's see how you can get a working mail sending server in all cases. You'll mainly need it to use the PHP mail() function. :D

We can find 3 different cases. We will test each one before passing to the next one, the best solution is first.



[h1]1. Use Sendmail[/h1]

Using sendmail is the best approach to send mail, because your server will not use any kind of external SMTP server to relay mails. It's also simple to install and does not require any kind of particular configuration.

[danger]If you already know your server network provider locks down the port 25 (which is required to send mails), or if you are using Gandi.net Cloud Hosting, you can go the the second case without considering this one.[/danger]

Connect to your server, and paste this in the terminal prompt (you must be root):

[code=bash]apt-get install sendmail[/code]

Then, restart your Web server software, like here if you are running Apache:

[code=bash]/etc/init.d/apache2 restart[/code]

Or if you are running Lighttpd:

[code=bash]/etc/init.d/lighttpd restart[/code]

Now, create a test PHP script and try to use the mail() function to send you a mail. PHP.net provides [url=http://php.net/manual/en/function.mail.php]a great documentation page[/url] about that function. B)



[h1]2. Use an external SMTP[/h1]

[h2]1. Gandi.net Cloud Hosting[/h2]

It recently appeared to me that Gandi.net was locking down the port 25 on its VPS (Cloud) servers. I believe they want to avoid some kind of spammers opening up a box for cheap and starting to send a bunch of mails through their network.

[question]The problem with the usage of Sendmail on their server was that - even if the outgoing mails were sent - the process was blazing slow (like 30 seconds) because of some port restrictions.[/question]

The only solution is to use their own SMTP server, as a relay for our outgoing mails. It will filter spam, [i]by the way[/i].


[h3]1. Create server email account[/h3]

Go to your domain administration panel on Gandi.net, and create an email account with the username you want, and the password you want.

[info]Don't forget those credentials, you'll need to use them later in the setup.[/info]


[h3]2. Setup sSMTP[/h3]

First thing to do for you is to install sSMTP on your web server. :p

Execute the following command:

[code=bash]apt-get install ssmtp[/code]

Then, open the sSMTP configuration file:

[code=bash]nano /etc/ssmtp/ssmtp.conf[/code]

Enter your credentials in the file you get, by changing the credentials and taking care of every option:

[code=bash]#
# Config file for sSMTP sendmail
#
# The person who gets all mail for userids < 1000
# Make this empty to disable rewriting.
root=myuser@mydomain.com

# The place where the mail goes. The actual machine name is required no
# MX records are consulted. Commonly mailhosts are named mail.domain.com
mailhub=mail.gandi.net:587

# Where will the mail seem to come from?
#rewriteDomain=

# The full hostname
hostname=myserverhostname

# Are users allowed to set their own From: address?
# YES - Allow the user to specify their own From: address
# NO - Use the system generated From: address
FromLineOverride=YES

UseSTARTTLS=YES

AuthUser=myuser@mydomain.com
AuthPass=mypassword[/code]

Then, press CTRL+O to save, and CTRL+X to exit.


Now, execute the following command:

[code=bash]nano /etc/ssmtp/revaliases[/code]

So that you get the following file (replace the bold characters by the email you previously created):

[code=bash]# sSMTP aliases
#
# Format:       local_account:outgoing_address:mailhub
#
# Example: root:your_login@your.domain:mailhub.your.domain[:port]
# where [:port] is an optional port number that defaults to 25.
root:myuser@mydomain.com:mail.gandi.net:587[/code]


[h3]3. Configure PHP[/h3]

The last step for you is to configure PHP so that it knows what command to execute to send the mails over the network.

If you are running Apache2, execute this command:

[code=bash]nano /etc/php5/apache2/php.ini[/code]

If you are running lighttpd, execute this command:

[code=bash]nano /etc/php5/cgi/php.ini[/code]

Then, press CTRL+W and type "sendmail_path". Press Enter. You'll be at the line we want to edit.

Replace this line with:

[code=bash]sendmail_path = /usr/sbin/ssmtp -t[/code]


Let's restart your server to finalize our configuration. B)

If you are running Apache2, execute this command:

[code=bash]/etc/init.d/apache2 restart[/code]

If you are running lighttpd, execute this command:

[code=bash]/etc/init.d/lighttpd restart[/code]


[h2]2. All other cases[/h2]

[h3]1. Setup eSMTP[/h3]

Let's install... the last solution we have! --'

Execute the following command:

[code=bash]apt-get install esmtp[/code]

Then, once done, open the eSMTP configuration file:

[code=bash]nano /etc/esmtprc[/code]

Edit the file so that you match the SMTP server of your choice. Take care of the lines in bold.

Here, in France, we can get this with Orange SMTP server (a French ISP):

[code=bash]# Config file for ESMTP sendmail

# The SMTP host and service (port)
hostname=smtp.orange.fr:587

# The user name
username=myaccount@orange.fr

# The password
password=mypassword

# Whether to use Starttls
#starttls=disabled

# The certificate passphrase
#certificate_passphrase=

# The Mail Delivery Agent
mda="/usr/bin/procmail -d %T"[/code]

Then, press CTRL+O to save and CTRL+X to exit.

Execute the following command to link eSMTP to the legacy Sendmail path:

[code=bash]ln -s /usr/bin/esmtp /usr/bin/sendmail[/code]


[h3]2. Configure PHP[/h3]

The last step (and most crucial one, we don't have any other solution for you if that one does not work!) for you is to configure PHP so that it knows what command to execute to send the mails over the network. ;)

If you are running Apache2, execute this command:

[code=bash]nano /etc/php5/apache2/php.ini[/code]

If you are running lighttpd, execute this command:

[code=bash]nano /etc/php5/cgi/php.ini[/code]

Then, press CTRL+W and type "sendmail_path". Press Enter. You'll be at the line we want to edit.

Replace this line with:

[code=bash]sendmail_path = /usr/bin/sendmail -t -i[/code]


Let's restart your server to finalize our configuration. B)

If you are running Apache2, execute this command:

[code=bash]/etc/init.d/apache2 restart[/code]

If you are running lighttpd, execute this command:

[code=bash]/etc/init.d/lighttpd restart[/code]


Lucky you are! Now your server can send mails from anywhere (but I think you mostly need it for PHP, eh?). 3:)

[i]Your Django website is now in production, hopefully it works great. When things are becoming south and some users start to get 500 errors, you change your settings so that Django auto-emails you the error traces. So far so good.[/i]

[b]Have you ever wondered about the volume of emails you may get in your inbox in case your website receives a lot of traffic that generates a lot of server errors?[/b] How can you avoid getting a thousand times the same error trace, and maybe missing some less-proficient errors while sorting your mail?

[b]Are you using GitLab to manage your project and address your issues?[/b] If you do, the following will make your life easier and save your time doing meaningless email sorting and manual issues creation and assignments.

[b]Well, that's what [url=https://github.com/valeriansaliou/django-gitlab-logging]Django GitLab Logging[/url] (django-gitlab-logging) is made for.[/b] Auto-open GitLab issues when the production server (or whatever) encounters 500 errors. Plus, smartly detect similar errors to avoid duplicating related issues.

[info]This tutorial is about a technology that we, the folks behind Waaave, have engineered to simplify our life. Everytime you encounter a 500 error on our website, the technology described below is used![/info]

Let's setup this on the top of our Django application stack. ;)

[steps]
    [step=1]
[h2]Install Django GitLab Logging[/h2]
In a terminal, execute the following command:
[code=bash]pip install django-gitlab-logging[/code]
Alternatively, if the package is not available on PyPi anymore, you can fetch it from GitHub:
[code=bash]pip install git+https://github.com/valeriansaliou/django-gitlab-logging[/code]
    [/step]

    [step=2]
[h2]Enable Django GitLab Logging[/h2]
Open your settings.py file from your Django website.
Then, add gitlab_logging to your [i]INSTALLED_APPS[/i]:
[code=python]INSTALLED_APPS = (
    # (...)
    'gitlab_logging',
)[/code]
    [/step]

    [step=3]
[h2]Configure Django GitLab Logging[/h2]
Drop those lines of configuration in your settings.py (at the end, the order has no importance):
[code=python]# GitLab options
GITLAB_HOST = 'https://gitlab.server.tld'  # Beware: no trailing slash there!
GITLAB_USER = 'gitlab.user'
GITLAB_TOKEN = 'USER_GITLAB_TOKEN'         # Get this from GitLab user account information
GITLAB_PROJECT_ID = 114                    # Get the project ID from the DB
GITLAB_ASSIGNEE_ID = 2                     # Get the assignee ID from the DB (optional, you can drop this parameter)[/code]
Now, take care of filling those settings. Here's a little more help about each option:
[ul]
    [*] [b]GITLAB_HOST[/b]: the GitLab protocol + host (e.g: https://code.hakuma.holdings)
    [*] [b]GITLAB_USER[/b]: the GitLab user that will automatically report issues (we recommend to create a dedicated user, to be seen as a bot)
    [*] [b]GITLAB_TOKEN[/b]: the login token associed to the GitLab user in use, you can get this from the user account page
    [*] [b]GITLAB_PROJECT_ID[/b]: the project ID to report issues to. Have a look to the [i]projects[/i] database table to grep the project ID (must be a number)
    [*] [b]GITLAB_ASSIGNEE_ID[/b]: the user ID to be assigned to every issue that is created (you can remove this option if you don't want to set an automatic assignee)
[/ul]
[warning]Beware! The GitLab URL defined in GITLAB_HOST must not contain the trailing slash! https://code.hakuma.holdings is valid, https://code.hakuma.holdings/ is invalid.[/warning]
    [/step]

    [step=4]
[h2]Setup Celery[/h2]
Django GitLab Logger requires Celery to be up and running as part of your Django stack. For those who don't know, Celery is a task runner, which allows you to delay tasks so that they are ran asynchronously, without blocking your main Django server thread during the task execution time.
If you don't have Celery installed, I recommend that you Google how to setup it (unless someone on Waaave write anything about how to setup it!) :p
    [/step]

    [step=5]
[h2]Update your database[/h2]
Django GitLab Logger makes a good use of the database to log issues that have been submitted to GitLab, so that it does not create more than enough similar issues.
Here we just need to synchronize our database:
[code=bash]./manage.py syncdb[/code]
If you are using migrations with South, execute this:
[code=bash]./manage.py migrate django_logger[/code]
    [/step]

    [step=6]
[h2]Activate the GitLab log handler[/h2]
We're nearly done! Now we just need to enable the custom logger that we have installed and configured.
In your settings.py, find the [i]LOGGING[/i] option, and add those dict items to the [i]handlers[/i] and [i]loggers[/i] keys:
[code=python]LOGGING = {
    # (...)
    'handlers': {
        # (...)
        'gitlab_issues': {
            'level': 'ERROR',
            'class': 'gitlab_logging.handlers.GitlabIssuesHandler',
        },
    },
    'loggers': {
        'django.request': {
            'handlers': ['django_file', 'gitlab_issues'],
            'level': 'ERROR',
            'propagate': True,
        },
        # (...)
    }
}][/code]
Of course, depending on your logging configuration, you will need to adapt the example above. :J
    [/step]
[/steps]

[b]Your Django website is now ready for error reporting![/b] Try to generate some 500 errors in your code, and observe how fast issues come to your GitLab project page!

[danger]If things don't appear to work as expected, always check the logs: either Celery logs or Django logs.[/danger]

[u]If you have any question, feel free to comment and ask them. ;)[/u]

Hope I made your day better! :D

Every good development process [b]consider separating the workflow in environments[/b] (settings, pieces of code and so forth). The main issue with Django is that it does not provide a way to manage environments [b]out-of-the-box[/b].

[b]At Waaave, we are using those techniques to optimize our workflow[/b]. Yes, we are also using Django, hence this tutorial :)

[info]If you come from the Ruby On Rails or NodeJS world, you might be used to such ways to organize your projects. We'll keep similar conventions there.[/info]

[h1]What Are Environments?[/h1]

[h2]The Story[/h2]

Let's consider you have a team of happy folks working on both frontend and backend code of your website, all from their local computers. [b]They might all share the same settings, but for different system settings[/b].

Then, they push their code to a staging server that simulates production, just in case last-minute bugs are discovered. [b]The system and project settings might vary depending on this testing platform[/b]. By the way, a CI (Continuous Integration) system run the tests they wrote for their code as soon as something is pushed on their Git repository.

Finally, they deploy their code to their remote production server, [b]which may also have different system settings[/b].

[h2]Let's Get To The Point[/h2]

Mhh, so... potentially we have [b]4 different environments[/b]. Here are the ones that we can generally see across all projects organized in environments:

[ul]
    [*] [b]Development[/b] - Used by the developer on his local machine (e.g: his MacBook)
    [*] [b]Testing[/b] - Used by the Continuous Integration system to run tests on the code (e.g: a runner on a dedicated server)
    [*] [b]Staging[/b] - Used by the staging server for pre-production testings (e.g: a dedicated server imitating the production system)
    [*] [b]Production[/b] - Used by the production server for final website serving (e.g: a cloud server accessed by end-users)
[/ul]

Now, [b]how do we separate Django in such environments[/b]? Well this is the topic of the next part. ;)

[h1]Use Environments With Django[/h1]

[h2]Setup Git Branches[/h2]

[i]This part is if you are using Git (or any other versioning system).[/i]

First of all, [b]we recommend that you separate your code[/b] for the development, staging and production environments [b]in branches[/b]. This way we can break things up in development branch and avoid affecting the stable branches that are staging and production. Thus, in case the sysadmin pull latest changes on production, he won't get your broken code until you explicitly merge it to the production branch. --'

We don't need a branch of the testing system (CI) since it's just there to check the consistency of our code. It'll basically test the code on the 3 remaining branches that are:

[ul]
    [*] [b]master[/b] - Used in development environment
    [*] [b]staging[/b] - Used in staging environment
    [*] [b]production[/b] - Used in production environment
[/ul]

[info]Since Git typically require a master branch to exist as the main - parent - branch, we don't create a "development" branch. The development code rather uses the "master" branch[/info]

[u]Here's how to create all the Git branches:[/u]

[code=bash]git checkout -b staging
git checkout -b production[/code]

[u]We push them to the remote Git server:[/u]

[code=bash]git push origin staging
git push origin production[/code]

[u]And then merge our changes:[/u]

[code=bash]git checkout master
git merge staging
git checkout staging
git merge production[/code]

[h2]Separate Django Settings[/h2]

Now that our Git repository is optimized for using environments, the last step is to [b]associate a settings file for every environment that we have[/b].

[steps]
    [step=1]
[h2]Create the settings directory[/h2]
Since we will store multiple configuration files, we need to put them in a directory.
[b]Create the settings directory first[/b] (in the same folder where your other Django apps live):
[code=bash]mkdir settings[/code]
    [/step]

    [step=2]
[h2]Move & rename settings.py[/h2]
Our old settings.py will now be used to save the common Django settings. Those settings will be shared across all environments.
[u]So let's rename it:[/u]
[code=bash]mv settings.py settings/common.py[/code]
    [/step]

    [step=3]
[h2]Initialize the settings[/h2]
Now, we need to [b]initialize the settings files as well as the reader[/b] that will extract our environment name and then open the correct file to be read:
[code=bash]touch settings/__init__.py
touch settings/development.py
touch settings/testing.py
touch settings/staging.py
touch settings/production.py[/code]
Open the "__init__.py" file that we created and drop the code below in it:
[code=python]import os
from common import *

try:
    import environment
except ImportError:
    pass

ENVIRONMENT = os.getenv("DJANGO_ENVIRONMENT") or "development"

if ENVIRONMENT == "production":
    from production import *
elif ENVIRONMENT == "staging":
    from staging import *
elif ENVIRONMENT == "testing":
    from testing import *
else:
    from development import *

try:
    from local import *
except ImportError:
    pass[/code]
    [/step]

    [step=4]
[h2]Create local settings[/h2]
You may need to define custom settings, that you don't want to share with your co-workers. Plus, we need to tell Django which environment we are working in locally. :)

[u]Execute the following commands:[/u]
[code=bash]touch settings/environment.py
touch settings/local.py[/code]
[warning]Make sure to add those files to your Git ignore file (.gitignore), as we don't want them to be versioned and then pushed on the remote Git repository.[/warning]
    [/step]

    [step=5]
[h2]Define our environment[/h2]
Then, [b]tell Django what your environment is[/b].

Open "local.py" and drop the following Python code:
[code=python]import os
os.environ["DJANGO_ENVIRONMENT"] = "development"[/code]

[info]Take care of changing the "development" value to your environment name, all low caps.[/info]
    [/step]

    [step=6]
[h2]Load our new settings[/h2]
Last step is to [b]tell Django where our new settings reside[/b].

Open both "wsgi.py" and "manage.py", find the line of code about settings loading and ensure it is:
[code=python]os.environ.setdefault("DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE", "settings")[/code]
Now you can restart your Django server and check if it is working.

[info]If something is wrong, Django will let you know. I assume the error messages are generally explicit enough so that you fix them ;)[/info]
    [/step]
[/steps]

All done! [i]Now, it is your turn to play with environments and move the settings you need to separate in the appropriate environment files![/i] 3:)
